intro: Galium gaudichaudii var. muriculatum, commonly known as the rough-stemmed bedstraw, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Pacific Northwest of the United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, often hairy stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of tiny, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its fruit is a small, dry capsule that releases seeds when mature. This species thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and streambanks.
